  physical_appearance: The image shows an elephant caparison. The textile that can be seen on the sides of the caparison come in a myriad of colours. Some fringes of yarn can be seen to be attached to these textiles. The centre of the caparison consists of a metal plate that is gold in colour. Several spheres of different sizes are embedded within the metal plate
 together with crescents forming a straight vertical line.

  sgcool_label_text: This ornate gold-plated nettipattam or caparison would have been part of the ornamentation of an elephant for a festival celebration in Kerala. This is a typical example of an elephant caparison
 with a core of copper coated with gold
 having five spherical fixtures and edged with a fringe of yarn
 backed with textile.\r\nThe nettipattam is symbolic of the elephant-headed god Ganesha. Elephants are central to large festivals and celebrations in Kerala
 with at least one decorated elephant being present at any large festival
 regardless of religion or community. Caparisoned elephants are particularly associated with the Thrissur Pooram
 an annual festival held at the Vadakkunnathan Temple in Thrissur
 Kerala.

Several spheres of different sizes are embedded within the metal plate, together with crescents forming a straight vertical line.

metadata.sgcool_label_text:
This ornate gold-plated nettipattam or caparison would have been part of the ornamentation of an elephant for a festival celebration in Kerala. This is a typical example of an elephant caparison, with a core of copper coated with gold, having five spherical fixtures and edged with a fringe of yarn, backed with textile.
The nettipattam is symbolic of the elephant-headed god Ganesha. Elephants are central to large festivals and celebrations in Kerala, with at least one decorated elephant being present at any large festival, regardless of religion or community. Caparisoned elephants are particularly associated with the Thrissur Pooram, an annual festival held at the Vadakkunnathan Temple in Thrissur, Kerala.
